data.text: Wild Camping vs Paid Camping when Bike Touring: Where Do You Stand?

What are peoples thoughts on wild camping when biking. It feels like a waste of money to pay ¬£30 for an electric pitch, which I would put a one man tent on for 10 hours, sleep and leave. I would be happy to pay ¬£10 but these sites seem to no longer me an option. I am looking in the Scarborough/ filey area.
anything is free as long u hide from main roads and dont get caught'
data.author: Ben Martin

data.text: Like Ben said. The world is big. You are not.
data.author: Dawn Alotta Seggs

data.text: well put üôÇ
data.author: Gregor Jeromen

data.text: absolutely wild camping is the way to go ¬£30 is a rip off ! Leave no trace take your rubbish home & nobody will know
data.author: Paul Wright

data.text: For me it's the need for a shower after 10 hours or so in the saddle in your lycras. I've tried the wet wipe wash but it doesn't cut it. I've done plenty of festivals and a bucket of water wash works OK. So how do you guys keep clean and fresh whilst wild camping ?
data.author: Pat McCarthy

data.text: embrace the stink same as with backpacking
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: I just want someone else ("someone special") to embrace my stink, too! ;-)
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: I normally embrace the stink but backpacking at Easter I developed a sweat rash for the first time. Think I'll try baby wipes next time.
data.author: Duncan McCollin

data.text: Believe it or not, a sort of "gentrification" also occurs in the area of campgrounds. Minimalists or, to put it bluntly, poor people and those of us who are against needless "luxuries," are shut out, excluded. It's up to some clear-eyed entrepreneurs to launch more "no frills" campgrounds at accessible prices (for the demand that would be there, the niche that IS there) or also for more municipalities to subsidize campgrounds. In some countries, like France, the very reasonably priced municipal campgrounds still exist, alongside private and more expensive ones. The capitalist types will tell you, if you can't afford to pay the full price, stay home, you don't deserve to travel. To them, having subsidized campgrounds is like paying taxes, i.e., stealing their money (from the rich to pay for the lazy poor), etc, etc. It's a political battle of ideas. If I could, I would set up a municipal campground or a no-frills minimalist campground. That being said, when touring, I really only need such campgrounds (or hostels, etc.) about once a week because I'm perfectly content with wild/stealth camping and baby-wipes for daily (evening) hygiene.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: I use a 5 liter foldable bag, something like a camel pack. 2 or 3 hours before stopping riding for the day, I look out for a water source, fill it up. Hang the bag on a branch and here goes the shower, it's far cooler to sleep clean. I do at 90% wild camping.
data.author: Nicolas Ossysek

data.text: I learned to make my own mobile "shower" using 2ltrs of water. I got a 2ltr water bottle, I made a joke on top of the bottle and use that hole to pour water in my hand and mix soap in it and get cotton handkerchief to wash my body with that little water and soap... And once entire body has been washed with soap and water I start slow process of rinsing my body slowly until it's like I just had a shower.. I often use about 1.5 liters to shower.. I shower that way daily wild camping for weeks and I never miss showers. Here's the advice; get into your shower and try it using any water bottle u have and you'll realize after about 5 times that u can shower with 2-3 liters so well and later u will see 1.5 liters enough. Tip; I carry extra 2 liters specifically for showering
data.author: Kyagera Ivan

data.text: for a basic wash all you need is 3 mouthful of water. One to spray on your upper body and essentials before soap, and two more to rinse after. Must be a funny sight in the forrest üòÖ. but it gets the job done, and the salt is off and the balls are happy Oh, bonus: keep it in the mouth for a few seconds for a warm shower üòÅüëåüèº
data.author: Julien Mjulr

data.text: go in a river or lake along the way
data.author: Embert Aarts

data.text: Also use sorbeline instead of soap.
data.author: Mark Coffey

data.text: All these comments make me feel so spoiled to be in Japan where there is a hot-spring bath to be found at the end of most any ride for about 550 yen (about 4 Euro?) sometimes less or once in a while free. It makes wild camping so easy. Just pick a bath on the map, scout a place in a park near the bath, shower and soak, rest, relax, eat, drink, then go to the park and pitch tent when the bath house closes.
data.author: Kevin Cameron

data.text: Depends on what you want. I like a warm shower, and sometimes to meet other campers, be a bit social. A campfire is sometimes nice too. Picnic table. Wild camping can be very isolating, and a bit stressful, with the feeling that you're hiding. For me it also feels not quite as secure. In terms of money, everyone is trying to earn a living. Many campgrounds are run by local families. I don't mind spreading a bit of money around to local economies. But it depends on how much you have and how long the journey is. Everyone has to figure out what works best for them.
data.author: Scott Boag

data.text: I do not mind spending money for good camping places with reasonable prices, where also tenters and solo travellers are welcome. I would like to support these good owners more. But have to find them first. Ironically, the cheap camping places, at around 10‚Ç¨ or equivalent, are usually also the good camping places. With separate tent meadow, some place to sit (sometimes covered) and not so crowded. Meanwhile, the expensive camping places usually offer less facilities, are fully parcellated, and less nice and more crowded. It makes no sense. If you pay the same or almost same as a caravan or campervan that uses 10x more space that translates to "hikers and cyclists are actually not welcome here but only tolerated if we can rip them off". Every coin going to these bad owners is one too much.
data.author: Wulfram Georg Tanner

data.text: I do it to wild camp. That‚Äôs the beauty of traveling by bicycle or on foot.
data.author: Giulia Juh√©

data.text: But at a campground you usually get a bathroom and shower and a table and place to make a fire, so not all bad.
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: and more likely to get your bike or stuff stolen if alone and you're off in the shower/toilet.
data.author: James Mckoy

data.text: perhaps, depends on where you are, in the USA 99% of campers are not bike thieves
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: it‚Äôs usually not the campers. People wander through looking for unattended stuff to steal. It‚Äôs a big problem in Australia and I have read similar posts about Europe.
data.author: James Mckoy

data.text: Costs have risen steeply on campsites - I have some short tours booked for this year with Premier Inn as low as ¬£24 for a twin room. You can take you bike to your room or they have space at ground level.
data.author: Tony Clarke

data.text: Premiere inn is virtually the same price as some campsites now
data.author: Michael Richards

data.text: I've been homeless for almost 8 months all I do is wild camp Who cares until you have a property owner yelling at you until then fuck it sleep wherever
data.author: Charles Kempf

data.text: You just need to find secluded spots
data.author: Charles Kempf

data.text: I have done a few nights wild then, drop in to a campsite for a good clean up
data.author: Michael Richards

data.text: I wild camp as much as possible
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: I still find plenty of campsites at around the ¬£10 Mark. I'm in the Lake District at the moment and can find plenty of pitches from. ¬£7.50 but there are plenty of wild camping spots also. I only use camp sites when I need to do laundry or use a kitchen or big fire
data.author: Fern Hume

data.text: Guerrilla Camping is the way. Ride a bike worth a couple k, camp for free.
data.author: Gir Affe Ponx

data.text: Wild camp as much as possible. Even resent paying for a campsite for the motorhome when I'm out in that. Admittedly it has a few more creature comforts than the bike
data.author: Paul Candy

data.text: I totally agree that ¬£30 for an electric pitch for a little tent is outrageous. I used one outside Paris a few years ago, when I started cycle touring again after a break of 29 years. (It was a very uncomfortable pitch as well, having been rutted by camper vans previously but the only one available.) On the other hand, cycling King Alfred‚Äôs Way last summer I used a combination of wild camping and a very nice campsite that cost me ¬£10, where the hot showers and company of others were most welcomeüôÇ
data.author: Keith Wood

data.text:
You can usually find a campsite that caters for tents without charging more for electric hookup, although some in popular spots are still pricey. https://www.ukcampsite.co.uk/ allows you to search for places that take tents (and also places that don't require you to be a member of the Camping & Caravanning Club), have showers etc.
The UK Camp Site for Tent and Caravan Campers in the UK with over 220,000 campsite reviews
ukcampsite.co.uk
data.author: Simon Lambourn

data.text: No, I am not going to pay ‚Ç¨30 for a camping spot. Even if I NEED a shower, I can find a pubic swimming pool and get clean for ‚Ç¨10 or less. Worse comes to worst, I can do a sponge off some place. I have found that one can ask a farmer to use their land offering them ‚Ç¨10. Never had a farmer turn me down, often they will let you camp for free.
data.author: Linda Tisue

data.text: When I went on a 5 month cycling trip, I had a pattern of wild camping for 3 nights and then staying in a hotel or B&B for 1 night (to shower, charge devices, sleep in a bed, socialise, restock food supply, reply to emails).
data.author: Lucy Hann

data.text: Only way to. As for showers just jump in a river. Or a small cup of water , or use some wipes. Cheapest way to see the world
data.author: Greg Scamporlino

data.text: If I use a campsite it‚Äôs usually because wild camp is not an option, and I have to make the most of the opportunity to charge electronics, shower, shave, wash and dry clothes etc. My last cycle trip (Falmouth to Madrid) I had 1 night in a campsite in Nantes where I needed to get some work done on the bike.
data.author: Ashley Hold

data.text: For 30¬£ i can buy an extra Anker powerbank
data.author: Marcel Oudhuis

data.text: Where we are this current moment!
data.author: Eli Lyons

data.text: I camped at a place on the Chilterns a couple of weeks ago. Just turned up and was asked for ¬£10 for the night. A very nice campsite too, even provided free tea, coffee and hot water for campers!
data.author: Phil Metcalfe

data.text: Mostly wild camping where there's water. If no water I might go to a camping place
data.author: Tommy B√§ck

data.text: Believe it or not, a sort of "gentrification" also occurs in the area of campgrounds. Minimalists or, to put it bluntly, poor people and those of us who are against needless "luxuries," are shut out, excluded. It's up to some clear-eyed entrepreneurs to launch more "no frills" campgrounds at accessible prices (for the demand that would be there, the niche that IS there) or also for more municipalities to subsidize campgrounds. In some countries, like France, the very reasonably priced municipal campgrounds still exist, alongside private and more expensive ones. The capitalist types will tell you, if you can't afford to pay the full price, stay home, you don't deserve to travel. To them, having subsidized campgrounds is like paying taxes, i.e., stealing their money (from the rich to pay for the lazy poor), etc, etc. It's a political battle of ideas. If I could, I would set up a municipal campground or a no-frills minimalist campground. That being said, when touring, I really only need such campgrounds (or hostels, etc.) about once a week because I'm perfectly content with wild/stealth camping and baby-wipes for daily (evening) hygiene.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: Exactly! I have stayed in municipal campgrounds in France where you drop 2 Euros in a drop box. Maybe those days are over. I have stayed in free camping areas where you're allowed to stay for a couple of days but then, because it's free, you get people trying to staying MUCH longer. Municipalities probably don't want to create areas that might attract the homeless, and/or local partiers, and people who might leave garbage and dirty toilets for the town to clean up. Sad situation. In Australia, many "no frills" campgrounds are just basic, wild campgrounds, some without running water, but even they can be expensive.
data.author: Marshall Bradbury

data.text: A year or so ago, as I was cycling through Portugal I stayed in the municipal campground in the city of Beja, where I had actually stayed a few nights 9 years earlier, and the price was still the same, 1,xx for me, 1,xx for the tent, a total of 2.35 EUR/night, with hot showers, and basic but very adequate facilities. That is a political decision, of course, of the politicians but also, ultimately, of the people (in a republican/democratic sense). Don't mean to criticize you, but it is too passive/negative to say "those days are over;" I mean, if we take into consideration that special (I consider true) definition of "politics" as being anything we do or say (it can be an action, like riding your bike, which might inspire people, or explaining something in a conversation or social media site), anything we do or say that leads to others changing their behaviour, or at least their way of thinking and then their behaviour (riding bikes or casting votes), that is politics. So I am being "political" at this very moment regarding this issue. Who knows who might be "influenced" or convinced, motivated, etc, upon reflecting on the issue in a different light, and then step up in this or that arena (or in a conversation of their own with other ultimately more or less influential people), through these words? I hope that the next time that I go through Beja, I can again stay in that same campground. It's not so much the money, but that too, it's the principle of the matter. In the meantime, just in case, so as not to let the idea or "principle" die, I/we should make sure that somewhere else there is at least another campground or two, or more, established elsewhere, to enhance the (informal) network of them, or at least to "replace" or substitute those that occasionally disappear.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: It is clear that you think cyclists SHOULD be tackling this problem wherever they might be. Personally, I neither have the inclination to do so nor the belief that I have enough knowledge or even the right to get involved. In any event, this is not an issue that presents itself to me as I'm cycling so there is no action to take. It is slightly unfair to call me passive when I can hardly be held accountable for ignoring a call to action that I didn't receive. As far as being negative, when I said "maybe those days are over" I was making a nostalgic reference. Although I don't care, you hardly know me well enough to characterize my writing as passive and negative. You're talking the talk; I hope you're walking the walk.
data.author: Marshall Bradbury

data.text: Don't take it so personally or as an "attack" on you (or what you wrote). I don't think only "cyclists" should be tackling this problem; everybody in general (who is aware of the situation and potential solutions/attitudes). But I find it interesting that so many people distance themselves from issues with the excuse that it is not "their" country, or their responsibility/accountability, etc, and then feel "personally" attacked. Relax! Normally (of course, you don't know that, as you don't know me as I don't know you... that can go on endlessly) I write for the person involved, OP or whomever, but also with the general public in mind. There are many people who might read this thread who have nothing to do with you or me. It's just an exchange of ideas, points of view, etc.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: You make a lot of assumptions about people. I hardly felt attacked nor did I take your comments personally. I was simply pointing out that I thought you were wrong. When you characterize a couple of innocuous phrases as passive/negative, it is clear that your intent is to criticize ideas rather than echange them, which you may or may not have any interest in doing. Maybe you're the one who needs to relax.
data.author: Marshall Bradbury

data.text: Way too complicated! :-) Just stick to the ideas.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: I'd rather not pay 20 EUR at two expensive campgrounds, do those two nights wild camping as well, and then spend those 40 EUR at a hotel. Why pay 20 EUR at a campground when you can stay in a hostel (ok, share a room with other people) for 12 or 15 EUR? I would only stay at a campground if it's in the 4-8 EUR range.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: Get a good battery for charging your gear for a few days. Saves 3-7 a night some places.
data.author: Patrick Delabie

data.text: I mix it up. Prefer wild camping for the solitude in beautiful back country areas. I try to find a water source where I can fill my 5L Ortlieb water bag, attach a shower nozzle and enjoy a well deserved wash. I hate going to bed without at least washing the essentials. And saving a bit of cash means a little extra available when you are having a tough day and need to spoil yourself. Campgrounds are great every now and then to enjoy a nice hot shower and chat to strangers, but the downside is the noise of passing cars/trucks and excitable campers. I always wake up more refreshed after wild camping in a nice secluded spot. Farmers are always accommodating when looking for a piece of ground to pitch the tent, and there is always water available. Just remember to leave the area as you found it. It‚Äôll make it easier for the next traveller who asks to camp there.
data.author: Peter McNulty

data.text: Love the shower bag, mine's not Ortlieb, cold shower better than no shower
data.author: Dennis Peterson

data.text: well said üö¥‚ù§Ô∏è
data.author: Teresa Meyaard

data.text: Wild camping is easy in some countries and, if you're very far off the beaten path, the only alternative. Many countries have limited camping which may only be available for a couple of months a year, even if it is inexpensive. I think wild camping just becomes the norm for some cyclists, a habit, one which greatly simplifies things on a daily basis. If you're willing to veer off the main roads on to quieter and quieter side roads, you're likely to find a place where you won't be bothered or even seen. I've camped in places where no car came by the entire time I was there. If you're obliged to go through areas which seem to be 100% agricultural and heavily fenced, you can always ask a farmer if you can pitch a tent on their land. I start thinking about spots at least an hour before sunset so I can find a decent, comfortable place to pitch my tent - in the hills, near water, in a forest or park - somewhere flat that's not too hard to get in and out of and where I can relax without worrying about getting "caught" and feeling like a criminal, which has only happened once. It was on a vineyard in Italy and when the farmer saw my bike he told me to stay as long as I liked. Wild camping gets easier and more comfortable the more you do it - like everything else. :)
data.author: Marshall Bradbury

data.text: bikepacking in Mexico is definitely like this, I mean it‚Äôs also kinda fun to find a place to pitch your tent every night (once you learn how to) and sometimes local people will offer food/water/a shower or place to sleep.
data.author: Malib√© Contreras

data.text: sounds exciting
data.author: David Leeuwangh

data.text: Ya. It really depends on where you want to go or where you are willing to go. I just cycled across Turkey and I not only had zero problems wildcamping, but I was able to find nice places to camp most nights with many great views - much nicer than many campgrounds I've stayed in. And in Eastern Turkey, I was often invited to stay with people as well.
data.author: Marshall Bradbury
Marshall Bradbury
Marshall Bradbury

data.text: I know a lot of people have success with church grounds. If someone is around just ask to pitch behind the church or somewhere in the grounds or just stealth camp behind out of site if nobody is there. I have never heard of anybody being asked to move on from Church grounds.
data.author: James Mckoy

data.text: It wouldn't be very Christian of them to ask you to move.
data.author: Tony Jackson

data.text: I would not be camping in a graveyard.
data.author: Melanie Elmer

data.text: exactly. I was riding in Vietnam in the countryside and a Buddhist monk came out and asked what we were doing ( in French which we didn‚Äôt speak) Gave us a tour of this massive monastery where there were just a couple of monks left. Asked us to stay but we had to move on. Worth asking regardless of the religious persuasion I reckon üòä
data.author: James Mckoy

data.text: I've done it, not directly on top of the graves, LOL, but within the enclosure. Then only when there was no other option. Sometimes just next to the cemetery, or behind it, there are often bushes, or adjoining woods.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: The long departed are not to be feared ...and if you happen to die in your sleep - well, the job's half doneü§£
data.author: Tony Jackson

data.text: About 30 years ago I was at a train station and my connecting train was canceled. I was going to sleep the rest of the night on the platform until the station manager told me I had 100% chance of getting robbed. I jumped the fence of the graveyard, covered myself in leaves and had a shocker of a sleep until dawn. Would have been fine if I had had a tent üòä
data.author: James Mckoy

data.text: yeah I‚Äôm taking a tent and sleeping bag, just in case I can‚Äôt find enough leaves. My tent is green so hopefully it won‚Äôt stand out too much.
data.author: Phil Lynn

data.text: it's the living I fear, incurring the wrath of locals üòÇ
data.author: Melanie Elmer

data.text: Hello For myself when i want to be clean , you camping, you have rivers,you have lakes, you have swimming pool ,you have farms,...you have seas , you have Adventures. I think its what you need. If you don't want that ,stay in your home...near your bathroom. We have MSR whisperlight universal. It's great
data.author: Mohamed Bouttefah

data.text: I did it in Scotland with the kids and it was fun. We swam daily so kept more or less clean. Making sure you bury your poo and then bin your used toilet paper is really important. I walk with someone who‚Äôs dog has developed the absolutely foulest habit of eating human poo - and we know it‚Äôs human because she comes out the bushes with dirty toilet paper in her mouth (ü§¢). Dig a hole to poop in, make sure it‚Äôs not near and waterways, or take it & your toilet paper home to dispose of later. We would bag it and bin it like we do with dog poo. Lots of smaller campsites have a range of options. Look for walk in pitches which don‚Äôt cost as much as the electrical pitches. If there‚Äôs a long distance foot path nearby you‚Äôll find more of these - Cleveland way or Penine way probably your closest.
data.author: Liz Johnson

data.text: I've done a lot of wild camping over the years (40) both backpacking and cycle camping. Each site needs to be considered on its own merits. Something rarely mentioned in articles about wild camping; the 'elephant in the room' is toileting! I carry a small trowel, dig a hole the night before in case it's a rush job in the morning. In grassland, the turf can be replaced and you'd hardly know! I little trick if there are likely to be people around, is to take down your inner tent, giving you a covered space in the outer tent to 'do the business'. Replace the turf, pack up your tent and no one's any the wiser. A small green tent is best for wild camping, the more out of sight the better. If you do happen to be discovered and asked to move - be courteous and move. The very few times when the landowner or his agent has confronted me, they've always been happy knowing I'll be gone in the morning. Often, if the landowner/tenant farmer's house is obvious, then I've asked, rarely being refused. However, now 70 years old (where the hell did that go!), I'm into mini-adventures now. No more three month trips. I tend to 'centre camp', staying on a site, going out on an unladen bike for the day exploring the local area. I do find sites which charge ¬£20 a night. I do think it would be good if sites could have an area for lightweight campers travelling under their own steam - but this is not a particularly good business model - we don't spend much!
data.author: Tony Jackson

data.text: I did it for 6 months. Pretty terrible when in a big city and people will not let you use the bathroom
data.author: Eric Robertson

data.text: I would LOVE to be able to feel secure enough to wild camp. But here in Croatia, depending on which region, there are bears, wolves, stray dogs, wild hogs, etc.... Even though bears are the only ones giving me panic attacks, i dont feel really safe with others either. Good thing in Croatia though, you can get a pitch on camp sites for 10-15‚Ç¨ for a small tent and 1 person, and you are free to use shower/toilet. So, not really bank-breaking like 30GBP you mention.
data.author: Ivan Perak

data.text: I‚Äôve stealth camped before but prefer regular campgrounds. I like to have a place. A shower, picnic table etc are all nice. Sometimes even if there‚Äôs a free campground with no showers I‚Äôll opt to move on to a paid one with a shower. Sadly more and more campgrounds are forbidding tents. Why allow tents when they can charge at least double, if not more, for an RV? Which isn‚Äôt even camping to begin with‚Ä¶.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: There are campsites that are cheaper, but going electric will put the price up, as will showers, shop, cafe and other facilities. Another thing with campsites in more populated areas is security. Time of year, holiday weekends, school holidays all see prices rise. So does being in tourist areas. It may also be worth looking at joining the Camping and Caravanning Club. Some sites give discounts, and there are other sites that are only open to members.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: I just did a quick search using CCC website for Scarborough for end of May midweek. Tent, grass with electric pitch - member price 18 quid, non members 27 quid. Tent grass non electric. Members 13 quid, non members 22 quid. There are also discount codes, not sure where you get those, I am sure if you join they will tell you.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Wild camping with a real campsite thrown in when necessary. I wouldn't pay extra for electricity as its generally 110 Volt so you couldn't connect to it. You can always find a socket somewhere on a campsite to use!
data.author: Philip Kilmurray

data.text: Camp anywhere you can
data.author: Bronwyn Laing

data.text: You can wild camp pretty much anywhere if you're sensible about it. My basic rules are to keep out of sight, and always carry a trowel so I can dig a small hole for the morning toilet. Pitch late and rise early. However there have been times when I couldn't find anywhere so I just kept riding through the night until I found a remote spot I liked and could rest up the next day. If you've got at least a days worth of food and water then it's no problem, though in hotter climates i was often carrying 6L of water.
data.author: Laurie Piper

data.text: Breakfast by the Danube...
data.author: Laurie Piper

data.text: Spot the Trowel!
data.author: Laurie Piper

data.text: Breakfast by the Rhine...
data.author: Laurie Piper

data.text: Thermarest Trekker chair on upturned Bicyle trailer, comfort and no backache!
data.author: Laurie Piper

data.text: Looks like you've got it all dialed in. One happy camper!
data.author: Marshall Bradbury

data.text: I don't count Km's or ascents - I enjoy the ride
data.author: Laurie Piper

data.text: It's all about being comfortable enough and rested to get back on the bike for another day of riding...
data.author: Guy Wilson

data.text: yes I would sleep better paying ¬£10 over ¬£30. Actually I might sleep like a baby in a free field lol.
data.author: Phil Lynn

data.text: The destination of my trip is one I have done a number of times visiting my parents. In the car this costs me approx ¬£90 including return. Given current situation this will continue to rise. As I have a bit of time on my hands I thought I‚Äôd do this journey on my bike, two nights there and two back. The aim to use time over money. The route and stop points are mainly coastal, so I could wash in the sea if needed. I think if I have the option to use a cheap campsite I will if I can find one on route, as I have struggled finding anything within my budget on the internet. I have wild camped before but this has been whilst hiking and a fair distance from the beaten track. When I am not able to find a campsite I will cycle until I find a spot to wild camp, or as suggested try and continue to cycle through the night depending on energy and temperature. I would be happy spending ¬£40 food not included. Thanks for all of your advice and experience.
data.author: Phil Lynn

data.text: why not join Warmshower's? There is now a small joining fee but well worth it. About 5 hosts in Scarborough, i am one, but away touring now. Tho i don't think you would have a problem finding a wild camping spot. Above the skate park on the sea front is a path that takes you up to the Castle. There are two level areas, picnic table too. Stunning spot to camp. Just take a trowel, tho there are toilets done near the skate park. My husband got the council to clear the grass and put the picnic tables in, stunning spot. Or on the south bay there is a large area of gardens going down from the Esplanade to the sea, you should be able to tuck away in there. All the cliff path too. Enjoy, and breath in that lovely sea air for me! Post a pic when there!
data.author: Debs Mutton

data.text: I just might do that, isn‚Äôt there puffins along part of the cliff edge.
data.author: Phil Lynn

data.text: no you have to go to Bempton area, just seagulls in Scarborough. Watch out when eating chips and ice-cream they swoop down and take it!
data.author: Debs Mutton

data.text: I am hoping that campsites start being a bit more sensible for bike packers and through hikers. A few i went to last year had different rates for us that made it reasonable I was seriously upset with a certain site asking ¬£40 a night for a field with a portable toilet and a tap
data.author: Judy Kimble Jarman

data.text: Never pay for sleep, so ridicules to pay for what we used to do normally, naturally. Just find a hidden spot, sleep, and leave without a trace.
data.author: Benjamin Moravec

data.text: Campsites all the way. Nothing beats a hot shower. Also fire bans make it unsafe to cook, in the wild.
data.author: Tim Attwood

data.text: On my previous tours I only use a campsite every couple of weeks or so, I'm basically paying for a shower, else I free-camp, or also use the wonderful warmshowers. org, a great way to meet others & also find good ahead route-info.
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: Waterloo, Ontario, Canada, here, not far from Scarborough, Ontario. Prices about the same, here. Almost everywhere has a fence or "No Trespassing" signs. Brutal. But not really that many other options. Campsites must be reserved weeks if not months in advance. 10 day trip is $450 - just to sleep! (Okay, so the parks are nice, but if I want to enjoy the park I'm probably not bicycle touring.) Currently hoping to make an approx. 1,200 km trip but the first night would put me in the middle of a city of over 2,000,000 people. Still trying to work that out. Wild camping in a city is tough. The city - Toronto - is a good day's ride across.
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: in England the majority of the land is owned by someone else, and you can get moved on, but I think if your not doing any harm it‚Äôs accepted. Scotland is different and you can camp wherever I think.
data.author: Phil Lynn

data.text: I've been through Toronto and was surprised at its immensity.
data.author: Ceecee Gowin

data.text: "Urban Sprawl".
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: I'd go around it if possible. Phoenix Arizona is the same.
data.author: Ceecee Gowin

data.text: Yeah, no. There is a great waterfront trail along the lakeshore. Coming home I will be about 160km (100 miles) north of the city. (Toronto is on the north shore of Lake Ontario, across from Buffalo, NY, for readers not familiar with the geography.) I will follow the lakeshore and then the St. Lawrence for almost two full days. I will find a solution. (Anyone reading live in T.O.?)
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: I've been to both cities and had no idea there was a bike trail on the waterfront. Sounds like a plan.
data.author: Ceecee Gowin

data.text: It looks wonderful. There is also a trail from Duluth, Minn. to Grand Portage, Minn. that is along Lake Superior. I'd be willing to bet you can circumnavigate the Great Lakes.
data.author: Ceecee Gowin

data.text: I wouldn't want to do it any other way and it's practical if you're on a tight budget. Bicycle travel makes touring possible for many who could not otherwise afford the trip.

data.author: Charles Dow Thomson

data.text: there's still a foot of snow up on the Yukon, but i managed to find this melted spot beside a clearing next to a gasoline cardlock, practically right in the town of Watson Lake. after a 150k day, i wanted a place i could take a day off. hidden in plain sight! I'll reply if anyone asks me to leave (not likely) stealth camping feels very empowering
data.author: Brent Joly

data.text: Its kinda nice to mix it up. Nothing beats a nice hot shower after a long days ride.
data.author: Jeremy Stein

data.text: Do what u feel like. Living frugal is what we should be adept to. Adventure and such trips a ther to build that attitude. Living off the land means real adventure.
data.author: Pradeep Kotnala

data.text: Travelodge is often cheaper than a campsite

data.text: I sleep and do a fire in the woods almost every weekend. I‚Äôm traveling there with a bicycle. Views and experience are very nice.

data.text: I never pay. Just go ask at a church or a fire station to pitch a tent in their yard.
